sledgehammer.event

Class EventHandlerContainer

  • java.lang.Object
    • sledgehammer.event.EventHandlerContainer

  • public class EventHandlerContainer
extends java.lang.Object
    CommandHandlerContainer is a container class for the event handler Annotation. This is to help cache and handle data and operations for event handlers in Sledgehammer. The method of invocation is through the MethodHandle API introduced in the JDK 1.7 version in order to handle methodical invocation that pre-compiles the data required to execute the method using the traditional reflection API, allowing the execution of the event handler to execute with the least amount of computations possible in the JVM.

    event handlers must contain one parameter for the method, which is the Event being interpreted and handled. If the parameters are not setup to only have the event being handled, the container will not be enabled. The handler will still be registered for debugging purposes.

    An example event handler is as follows:

    EventHandler(ignoreCancelled = true, priority = 5) private void on(ChatMessageEvent event) { // Handle Event here. }

    Author:
    Jab

    • Constructor Detail

      • EventHandlerContainer

        public EventHandlerContainer(Listener container,
                             java.lang.reflect.Method method,
                             EventHandler annotation)
        Main constructor.
        Parameters:
        container - The Object to identify with the event handler. This is typically the declaring class.
        method - The Method that is the event handler to invoke.
        annotation - The event handler Annotation that contains the information important to the functions of the event handler.

    • Method Detail

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • handleEvent

        public void handleEvent(Event event)
                 throws java.lang.Throwable
        Handles an Event. If the event handler is not enabled, then we return without attempting to handle the Event.
        Parameters:
        event - The Event passed to handle.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Throwable - Thrown if the event handler fails to handle the Event, or the MethodHandle fails to invoke.

      • getMethod

        public java.lang.reflect.Method getMethod()
        Returns:
        Returns the Method that is the event handler being invocated when handling Events.

      • getAnnotation

        public EventHandler getAnnotation()
        Returns:
        Returns the Annotation instance storing the meta-data for the event handler.

      • getContainer

        public Listener getContainer()
        Returns:
        Returns the container for the Method to invoke.

      • getPriority

        public int getPriority()
        Returns:
        Returns the priority index for the event handler. The higher the number, the more priority the event handler has over other event handlers, and will be invoked first.

      • ignoreCancelled

        public boolean ignoreCancelled()
        Returns:
        Returns true if the event handler handles the Event, even if the event is cancelled by a prior event handler.

      • getId

        public java.lang.String getId()
        Returns:
        Returns the String ID (if defined), for the event handler.

      • isStatic

        public boolean isStatic()
        Returns:
        Returns true if the event handler is declared as a static method.

      • getMethodParameters

        public java.lang.Object[] getMethodParameters()
        Returns:
        Returns the Parameters for the Method.

      • isEnabled

        public boolean isEnabled()
        Returns:
        Returns true if the event handler is enabled. When this is disabled, Events will not be passed and handled.

      • setEnabled

        public void setEnabled(boolean flag)
        Sets the event handler as enabled. When this is disabled. Events will not be passed and handled.
        Parameters:
        flag - The status to set.

      • getEventClass

        public java.lang.Class<? extends Event> getEventClass()
        Returns:
        Returns the Class of the Event to handle.

      • getTimeCreated

        public long getTimeCreated()
        Returns:
        Returns the UNIX Timestamp for the container to identify when the contained was created.
